1100425569592897538.text: Finally, given the case law, there's unlikely to be much of a First Amendment payoff to a "fiduciaries" approach. Yet the costs are notable. Critically, it diverts attention away from Facebook's dominance & business model, which are the key sources of many FB-based harms.

1100425568787537920.text: Fourth, in traditional fiduciary relationships, the user understands the terms of the relationship. 1100425568045223936.text: Third, unlike doctors--who can provide expertise only through collecting sensitive patient information--Facebook is a communications network. Sharing personal information with Facebook is not a functional prerequisite to using Facebook. It's the price Facebook has chosen to set.

1100425566526808065.text: Second, a fiduciary duty to users would be in perpetual conflict with Facebook's business model, which incentivizes surveillance. 1100425565222391808.text: First, firms like Facebook already have a fiduciary duty: to shareholders. 1091803511803822081.text: In short, structural separations have a rich history! More to come in a forthcoming paper https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3180174 …

1091803505747288065.text: In some instances, separations were applied to promote goals like media diversity, dispersion of power, or system stability. The fact that separations are easier to administer & police than standalone prohibitions on discrimination also weighed in favor of structural rules.

1091803240323260416.text: Yes, many retailers offer private labels. What partly guided previous separations was whether the intermediary was a bottleneck. This reflected the view that self-privileging by the intermediary risks distorting competition when producers lack real alternative channels to market.

1091459168509353986.text: We applied a similar rule to TV networks, telecom carriers, banks. There's good reason to debate whether structural separations should apply to digital monopolies. But framing the rule as highly invasive or exotic misunderstands our own history (& success) applying it

1091459167687188480.text: Interestingly, @nytimes describes India's rule as "protectionism." But this sort of structural separation has been a key principle in US competition policy. For example, Congress in 1906 passed a law prohibiting railroads from transporting goods they ownedhttps://www.nytimes.com/2019/01/30/technology/amazon-walmart-flipkart-india.html …

1091459166785490944.text: The rule responds to a problem that merchants selling on Amazon routinely face: Amazon will spot their best-selling products and then produce an Amazon-branded version, demoting them in search listings and eating their saleshttps://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-04-20/got-a-hot-seller-on-amazon-prepare-for-e-tailer-to-make-one-too …

1091459165833388032.text: India has introduced a new rule prohibiting e-commerce platforms from selling their own goods on the platform. The idea is you can either run the marketplace, or sell your goods on the marketplace, but not bothhttps://www.bbc.com/news/business-47083972 …

1004424669422813185.text: Press coverage of the lawsuit is here https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/may/24/mark-zuckerberg-set-up-fraudulent-scheme-weaponise-data-facebook-court-case-alleges … and our amicus is here https://openmarketsinstitute.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/06.05-OMI-Amicus-Brief-Opposing-FB-Motion-to-Seal-.pdf …

1004424173727436801.text: Lawsuit alleges that Facebook cited user privacy as justification for cutting off apps. We know, of course, that privacy was hardly one of Facebook's top priorities. But this maps onto a larger pattern of FB using privacy concerns as a guise for actions that entrenched its power

1004422086545330176.text: Facebook also is alleged to have created a "blacklist" of companies that Facebook would cut off - a list that Zuckerberg personally managed. Who was blacklisted? Companies that Facebook deemed potential competitors

1004421165639766016.text: Moreover, the allegation is that Facebook didn't actually tell all developers about this new policy. So thousands of developers continued to invest in building apps on Facebook-- only to later learn they no longer had access to the data Facebook had originally promised

1004420863909908486.text: In short, the allegation is that Facebook initially lured developers onto its platform by granting free access to user data. But once its desktop business started doing badly, Facebook needed to boost its mobile ad business. So it forced developers to buy mobile ads for access

1004419594302390272.text: A lawsuit against Facebook alleges it employed an anticompetitive & fraudulent scheme to maintain & extend its dominance. Now FB is trying to seal the evidence. Yesterday @openmarkets filed an amicus brief asking the court to keep these records public https://openmarketsinstitute.org/wp-content/uploads/2018/06/06.05-OMI-Amicus-Brief-Opposing-FB-Motion-to-Seal-.pdf …

979770175204528134.text: It’s difficult to overstate what a remarkable judge and jurist Stephen Reinhardt was. Too often the legal profession cultivates a certain timidity, a reluctance to say what is Just and Unjust

979765859634827264.text: In critical areas, he witnessed the Court transform legal doctrine from a tool of justice to a tool of injustice. And he was unrelenting in calling this out for the travesty that it ispic.twitter.com/drSimyVT9h

979764220823818240.text: He was particularly fearless and insistent in defending the rights of minorities, the poor, and the powerless, and in recognizing how unequal and unjust their experience of America was on a day to day basispic.twitter.com/4RdGoG5bbE

979763953722122240.text: It captures, in one place, his fierce eloquence, his sharp brilliance, and the deep sense of injustice he felt when seeing legal institutions undermine constitutional rights rather than protect them
